questions.text: What is the role of inhibin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Inhibits the secretion of FSH

Explanation:

  • Inhibin from the granulosa cells inhibits FSH secretion.
  • It is a hormone primarily produced by the ovaries (in females) and testes (in males).
  • It regulates the reproductive system by inhibiting the secretion of FSH (Follicle-Stimulating Hormone) from the anterior pituitary gland.
  • Inhibin suppresses the FSH
    • Inhibin B: Before ovulation
    • Inhibin A: After ovulation

 

Stimulates the secretion of FSH (Option A): Inhibin does not stimulate FSH release; instead, it inhibits it. FSH is involved in the growth and maturation of reproductive cells, but inhibin reduces its secretion once the follicle or sperm production reaches sufficient levels.

Inhibition of PRL (Option C) and Stimulation of PRL (Option D): Inhibin does not directly regulate prolactin (PRL), a hormone involved in milk production. PRL levels are primarily controlled by dopamine from the hypothalamus and other factors, not by inhibin. Therefore, inhibin neither inhibits nor stimulates PRL production.

questions.text: In the cervical smear below, which of the following stains are used
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Papanicolaou stain

Explanation:

  • Papanicolaou stain is the standard stain used in cervical smears to detect cellular abnormalities.
  • The Pap stain results in:
    • Well-stained nuclear chromatin
    • Differential polychromatic counterstaining of the cytoplasm
    • Cytoplasmic transparency

H & E stain (Option B) (hematoxylin and eosin) staining procedure uses two dyes to stain tissue samples, making it easier to see cell structure under a microscope; this is commonly used for histopathological tissue sections, not for cervical smears.

Giemsa stain (Option C) is used to stain blood and bone marrow smears, as well as some parasites, but it is not used in cervical cytology.

Toluidine blue (Option D) is a basic metachromatic dye primarily used to stain acidic components of tissues, such as nucleic acids and mast cell granules. It is not used for routine cervical cytology.

questions.text:
Which of the following tumour markers are positive for seminoma?


	PLAP
	OCT3/4
	NANOG
	HCG
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 3 and 4

Explanation:

  • Seminomas are characterized by specific tumour markers like
    • PLAP (Placental alkaline phosphatase)
    • HCG
    • LDH
    • Newer markers:
      • OCT ¾
      • NANOG
      • CD117
      • SALL4
  • Seminoma is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis.
  • A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma, and germinoma is present in the pineal gland.
  • Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade.
  • Gross:
    • Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is NOT caused by high-risk strains of human papillomavirus (HPV)?
questions.solution:
Laryngeal papillomas are benign lesions primarily associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11. These serotypes are known to cause condyloma acuminatum and are commonly associated with laryngeal lesions, particularly in children and young adults

 

Types of HPV
 

Cutaneous involvement

HPV 1, 2, 3 (low risk)
  • Filiform wart
  • Verruca Plantaris

HPV 5, 8 (high risk)
  • Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
 

Mucosal involvement

HPV 6, 11 (low risk)
  • Condyloma Acuminatum
  • Recurrent laryngeal papillomas

HPV 16, 18, 31, 33, 35 (high risk)
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

HPV 16 (High risk)
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Oropharyngeal SCC

HPV 18 (High risk)
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma cervix
  • Anogenital carcinoma


 

Cutaneous involvement

Benign Warts

  
  • Common Skin Warts (Verruca Vulgaris): Small, hard, rough growths on the skin; commonly seen in children (associated with serotypes 2, 4, 27, 57).
  • Flat Warts (Verruca Plana): Also prevalent among children.
  • Plantar Warts (Verruca Plantaris): Benign lesions commonly found in adolescents (linked to serotype 1).

Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis
  • Rare autosomal recessive conditions may progress to squamous cell carcinoma, especially in sun-exposed areas.
  • Associated with serotypes 5, 8, 9, 12, 17, 20, 36, and 47.

Mucosal involvement

Anogenital Warts

  
  • It is also known as Condyloma Acuminatum.
  • A sexually transmitted infection in adults, associated with HPV serotypes 6 and 11.

Head and Neck Lesions

  
  • Benign: Recurrent laryngeal papillomas, especially in children (serotypes 6, 11).
  • Malignant: Laryngeal and esophageal carcinomas (serotypes 16, 18)

Carcinoma Cervix
  • Mainly squamous cell carcinoma, linked to high-risk serotypes like 16, 18, 31, 33, and others.
  • Serotype 16 alone accounts for ~50% of cases, while serotypes 16 & 18 together cause ~70% of cervical cancers.

questions.text: What is the most probable tumour that a 22-year-old woman with a sizable growth in her right ovary, which has been determined to originate from all three germ layers based on histopathology, is experiencing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Teratoma

Explanation:

  • Teratomas are tumours that originate from all three germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) and are commonly found in the ovaries.
  • They are often seen in young women and can contain a variety of tissue types, such as hair, teeth, and muscle, which reflects their origin from all three germ layers.

Immature teratoma:

  • Bulky, solid ovarian tumours that contain immature neuroepithelium, cartilage, bone, and muscle, with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage.
  • They grow rapidly, often spreading beyond the ovary.
  • They are seen in young females and have a high risk of malignancy.
  • They have small, round blue cells (Immature neural components).

Mature teratoma

  • Mature teratomas, or dermoid cysts, are common benign ovarian tumours found in young women. They are bilateral in 10-15% of cases.
  • They contain tissues from all three germ layers, including skin, hair, and teeth, and can rarely undergo malignant transformation to squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Grossly, they are unilocular cysts with a thin wall and hair; microscopically, they have stratified squamous epithelium and sebaceous glands.

 

Monodermal teratoma:

  • Monodermal teratomas consist predominantly of a single type of tissue, such as thyroid tissue in struma ovarii or neuroendocrine cells in carcinoid tumours. They lack immature or embryonic-like tissues and typically do not have a high risk of malignancy.

 

Dysgerminoma (Option A) is also a type of germ cell tumour (GCT) that typically secretes beta hCG.

 

Thecoma (Option C) is a rare benign tumour originating from the ovarian stroma, accounting for less than 1% of all ovarian tumours. It is most commonly found in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women.

 

Theca lutein cysts (Option D) are rare benign cystic lesions caused by hypertrophy of the theca interna layer due to excessive stimulation by hCG.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 48-year-old patient who came with scrotal swelling, had elevated LDH levels but normal AFP levels on tests for testicular tumours, and exhibited a specific histological picture after orchidectomy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Seminoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and histopathological findings suggest testicular seminoma.
  • Seminomas elevate LDH levels, while AFP remains normal.
  • Histology shows large, uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli.

Seminoma:

  • It is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis.
  • A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma, and germinoma is present in the pineal gland.
  • Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade.
  • Genetics: Seminomas contain isochromosome 12p and express OCT3/4 & NANOG.
  • Morphology: Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.
  • Histology of seminoma:
    • Sheets of monomorphic cells.
    • The sheets are divided into poorly demarcated lobules by the septa of the fibrous tissue.
    • The septa show lymphocytic infiltration (T lymphocytes).
    • The classic seminoma cell is large and round to polyhedral with a distinct cell membrane and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli.
    • The cytoplasm is clear or watery appearing and contains glycogen.
    • The arrows in the image below show seminomatous tumour cells.

Source: https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Testis_seminoma_3.jpg

 

Testicular Tumour

Corresponding Tumor Markers

Seminoma
  • Placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP)
  • HCG
  • LDH
  • Newer markers: Oct 3/4, Nanog, CD117, SALL4

Embryonal Carcinoma
  • CD-30

Yolk sac tumour
  • Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP)
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin

Choriocarcinoma
  • Beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (β-hCG)

Teratoma
  • Cytokeratin

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Meigs syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Dysgerminoma of the ovary

Explanation:

  • Dysgerminoma is a type of germ cell tumour and is not part of Meigs syndrome.

Meigs Syndrome: Meigs syndrome is a condition characterised by a triad of:

  • Ovarian fibroma (fibrothecoma)
  • Ascites
  • Hydrothorax (pleural effusion)

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate concerning liquid-based cytology?

choices.text: Study of fluid in the tumor microenvironment

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Urine specimen is used

Explanation:

  • Liquid-based cytology is often used to collect specimens, including urine, and study cells for various diagnostic purposes.

Liquid-based cytology:

  • It is a technique to collect and prepare cell samples for microscopic analysis.
  • It involves gathering cells from various body fluids, such as cervical or vaginal fluids, respiratory secretions, or urine, depending on the diagnostic goal.
  • This method is commonly used for cervical cancer screening. Cells collected from the cervix with a brush or spatula are suspended in a preservative solution. This suspension is used to prepare slides for cytological examination to detect abnormalities or disease.
  • Advantages of Liquid-Based Cytology (LBC):
    • Improved slide preparation: LBC creates a thin-layer or monolayer slide preparation, providing better quality and clarity than conventional Papanicolaou (Pap) smears.
    • Enhanced cell preservation: The collection fluid used in LBC fixes, homogenizes, and rinses the cells, ensuring better preservation for microscopic examination.
    • Reduced sample contamination: The homogenization process minimizes the presence of non-representative material, such as blood or mucus, leading to a more accurate analysis of the collected cells.
    • Increased diagnostic accuracy: With improved sample quality, LBC enhances the sensitivity and specificity of cervical cancer screening, allowing for more reliable detection of abnormalities.
  • Disadvantage:
    • Although cervical cytological screening has proven effective in reducing the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer, the conventional Pap test is less sensitive than commonly thought. The false-negative rate of the conventional Pap test has been reported to reach as high as 50%.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a constituent of the Papanicolaou stain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Eosin B

Explanation:

  • Eosin B is not a constituent of the Papanicolaou stain. Eosin is a different type of stain typically used for general histology to highlight cytoplasm in tissues, but it is not used in the Papanicolaou (Pap) stain.
  • The Papanicolaou (Pap) stain is a widely used technique for examining cells from the cervix to screen for cervical cancer and other abnormalities. It uses a combination of multiple dyes to differentiate cellular components:
    • Hematoxylin - Stains the cell nuclei, allowing for clear visualization of nuclear structure.
    • Orange G - Stains keratinized cells orange, highlighting squamous cells.
    • Eosin A - Second counterstain & a polychrome mixture of Eosin Y and Light Green (stains cytoplasm and helps differentiate between various cell types).

questions.text: A patient presents with ascites and omental caking. Imaging reveals solid components in an adnexal mass, and there is a long-standing history of symptoms. CA-125 is positive. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Serous ovarian tumor

Explanation:

  • The presence of ascites, omental caking, a solid adnexal mass, elevated CA-125, and chronic vague symptoms strongly points to serous ovarian tumor.

Types of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor:

Type of Epithelial Ovarian Tumor

Characteristics

Clinical Presentation

Serous Tumors

 

Serous Cystadenoma: Benign, unilateral, cystic spaces with serous epithelium.

Large cystic mass, unilateral.

 

Serous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, often bilateral, cystic and solid components.

Bilateral involvement in 30%, elevated CA-125.

Mucinous Tumors

Mucinous Cystadenoma: Benign, unilateral, filled with mucinous fluid.

Large, unilateral mass.

 

Mucinous Cystadenocarcinoma: Malignant, unilateral, mucinous epithelial lining.

May rupture and spread to the peritoneum.

Endometrioid Tumors (Option C ruled out)

Endometrioid Carcinoma: Arises from endometrial-like tissue, solid and cystic.

Solid and cystic components, associated with endometriosis.

Clear Cell Tumors

Clear Cell Carcinoma: Clear cytoplasm due to glycogen accumulation.

Advanced stage, associated with endometriosis.

Brenner Tumors (Transitional Cell)

Brenner Tumor: Transitional epithelial cells resembling urinary tract epithelium.

Rare, usually benign.

Mucinous ovarian tumor (Option B) typically presents as a large, unilateral, multiloculated cystic mass and is less commonly associated with peritoneal spread or omental caking. CA-125 elevation is not as prominent unless the disease is advanced, and it lacks the classic imaging and spread pattern seen in serous carcinoma.

Granulosa cell tumors (Option D) are sex cord-stromal tumors that secrete estrogen and often cause hormonal symptoms like abnormal uterine bleeding; they rarely cause ascites or omental caking, and CA-125 is typically not elevated.

questions.text:
A histopathological image of an ovarian mass in a lady is shown below. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition?




	Sex cord stromal tumor
	Call-Exner bodies are seen
	CA125 is high
	Inhibin is a marker
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1, 2, 4

Explanation:

  • The ovarian tumor showing Call-Exner bodies on histopathology is most consistent with a Granulosa Cell Tumor, a type of Sex Cord-Stromal Tumors, for which inhibin serves as an important diagnostic marker.

Feature

Sertoli-Leydig tumour,

Pure Leydig tumour (or Hilus cell tumour)

Fibroma, Thecoma, Fibrothecoma

 

Granulosa Cell Tumor

 

 

Derived from

Sertoli or Leydig cells

Ovarian stroma

Granulosa cells of ovarian follicle

Age of Occurrence

Second and third decades

Any age

Postmenopausal (adult type), any age (juvenile type)

Associated symptoms

Abnormal sexual development or Virilization

Associated with Meigs syndrome and basal nevus syndrome

Precocious sexual development in juveniles or abnormal uterine bleeding, endometrial hyperplasia (carcinoma) in adults

Histological features

Reinke crystalloids (in pure Leydig cell tumours)

 

 

Well-differentiated fibroblasts (fibroma),
plump spindle cells with lipid droplets (thecomas)

Call-Exner bodies, Coffee bean nuclei

(Statement 2)

Mutations & Markers

Mutations in DICER1 (which encodes endonuclease)

Vimentin +,
Thecoma: Oil Red O +ve
Fibroma: Oil Red O -ve

Elevated inhibin levels, CD99+, and FOXL2 mutations (in adult cases)

(Statement 4)

 

Prognosis

Low recurrence or metastasis rate (<5%)

Benign; Rarely malignant (fibrosarcomas)

Potentially malignant with unpredictable behaviour;

10-year survival rate 85%

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a painless testicular mass. An ultrasound shows a well-circumscribed, homogeneous, non-hemorrhagic testicular tumour. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Seminoma

Explanation:

The given histopathological image shows features suggestive of testicular seminoma.

Histology of seminoma:

  • Sheets of monomorphic cells.
  • The sheets are divided into poorly demarcated lobules by the septa of the fibrous tissue.
  • The septa show lymphocytic infiltration (T lymphocytes).
  • The classic seminoma cell is large and round to polyhedral with a distinct cell membrane and a large, central nucleus with one or two prominent nucleoli.
  • The cytoplasm is clear or watery appearing and contains glycogen.
  • The arrows in the image below show seminomatous tumour cells.

 

Seminoma:

  • It is the most common germ cell tumour of the testis.
  • A similar presentation in the ovary is called dysgerminoma, and germinoma is present in the pineal gland.
  • Incidence: Peak incidence in the fourth decade.
  • Genetics: Seminomas contain isochromosome 12p and express OCT3/4 & NANOG.
  • Gross:
    • Seminoma has a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.
    • Generally, the tunica albuginea is not penetrated, but extension to the epididymis, spermatic cord, or scrotal sac occasionally occurs.

questions.text: A patient presents with an ovarian mass that is multiloculated and has a serum CA-125 level >1000 U/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D)Serous Cystadenocarcinoma

Explanation:

  • Serous cystadenocarcinoma is the most common malignant epithelial ovarian tumour, often bilateral, and tends to be multiloculated with papillary projections.
  • CA-125 is a tumour marker for epithelial ovarian cancers, especially serous and endometrioid types.
    • A very high CA-125 (>1000 U/mL) is far more suggestive of malignancy than benign lesions.
    • Patients often present with abdominal distension, ascites, and an adnexal mass.

Incorrect Options:

Serous cystadenoma (Benign epithelial tumour) (Option A): Usually unilocular or mildly multilocular, with thin walls and clear serous fluid.
CA-125 levels may be normal or only mildly elevated, not usually >1000. There is no invasive growth, and it occurs in younger women compared to cystadenocarcinoma

Mature teratoma (Dermoid cyst) (Option B): Benign germ cell tumour containing ectodermal derivatives like hair, teeth, and sebaceous material. It usually occurs in younger women (teens to early adulthood).

  • CA-125 is not a typical marker; instead, you might find elevated AFP or β-hCG in other germ cell tumours (not teratomas).

On imaging, it often has fat-fluid levels or calcifications, not a multiloculated cystic appearance.

Granulosa cell tumour (Sex cord–stromal tumour) (Option C): Often estrogen-producing may cause precocious puberty in children or postmenopausal bleeding in older women.
Serum marker: Inhibin (not CA-125).

  • Usually, a solid or cystic-solid mass, not a multiloculated cyst with such high CA-125.

questions.text: What is the most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Mediastinum

Explanation:

Extra-gonadal germ cell tumor:

  • The most common site for an extragonadal germ cell tumor is the mediastinum.
  • Extragonadal germ cell tumors can be benign or malignant.
  • Benign extragonadal germ cell tumors are called benign teratomas: These are more common than malignant extragonadal germ cell tumors and are often very large
  • Malignant extragonadal germ cell tumors are divided into two types:
    • Seminoma
    • Non-seminoma
